image.altText: A man of East Asian background wearing medical scrubs. He is a wheelchair user

items.synopsis: Dr Dinesh Palipana says a ground crew member at Brisbane Airport ignored his carers and manoeuvred his wheelchair sharply, tipping him onto the ground.

title.children: Investigation launched after doctor and disability advocate tipped out of wheelchair at Brisbane Airport

image.altText: Police cars parked on the footpath of a suburban street.

items.synopsis: Police have charged a 55-year-old woman with murder after a 73-year-old woman was discovered dead in a property in the Mackay suburb of Glenella.

title.children: Daughter charged with murder after mum found dead in north Queensland home

image.altText: Composite image with a side profile of a man, with a blurred Christian cross and abstract church windows behind him.

items.synopsis: A sacked Brisbane principal whose ouster prompted weeks of protests from parents at St Paul's School has revealed a years-long dispute over $6.5 million in payments to abuse victims preceded his departure.

title.children: Sacked principal from Brisbane private school reveals $6.5m row over funding abuse victims

image.altText: A blank Voice to Parliament ballot paper

items.synopsis: Dozens of constitutional and public law teachers from across the country have signed a letter in a bid to tackle "misunderstandings and misconceptions" about the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Voice 'is not constitutionally risky', say 71 law professors in open letter to Australian public

image.altText: Director Nash Edgerton and Briggs on set for their skit at a pub.

items.synopsis: It starts with a conversation you might have had with a friend or family member over the last few months.

title.children: How an Australian rapper's Yes referendum skit was viewed by millions

image.altText: A side by sad image of Anthony Albanese wearing a purple tie and a woman wearing a pink hat behind a microphone

items.synopsis: From a 17-minute video on a far-right website to the prime minister's talking points — ABC Investigations reveals how a conspiracy theory has taken social media by storm.

title.children: How a former Neighbours star triggered an avalanche of fears about the Voice being a secret UN land grab

image.altText: A white dog looking through the cage door of its kennel.

items.synopsis: Certain dog breeds are banned from being imported to Australia, but residents are allowed to own them in Queensland under certain circumstances. The government wants to change that, but some experts think it's not the answer.

title.children: Queensland is cracking down on dangerous dogs, but some say banning them is complicated

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in a historic building.

items.synopsis: Analysis of more than 3,000 bank branches nationally suggests hundreds of regional locations are at risk of being closed, in addition to more than 1,600 closed around the country in the past six years.

title.children: Hundreds of regional bank branches are 'at risk' of closing, but 'there's no easy solution' to solve the problem

image.altText: A computer screen shows the Defence Health logo and options for insurance and contacting the company.

items.synopsis: One member is told just moments before a medical procedure that she will have to foot a $1,250 bill because she is not a financial member.

title.children: Hundreds of complaints after health insurer's IT glitch leaves customers with big medical bills and unpaid claims

image.altText: Protest at busy roundabout, Martlesham, Suffolk, England, UK Climate Emergency is a scam, no to cashless society.

items.synopsis: The United States has a long history with conspiracy theories, and Australia isn't immune to them either.

title.children: Lizard people, the Illuminati and the CIA: How conspiracy theories thrive on fear

image.altText: A small baby sitting up and smiling at the camera with a breathing tube in her nose.

items.synopsis: Ivy was born 15 weeks early and spent the first few months of her life in intensive care. When she finally came home, her parents found most people did not understand what they had experienced.

title.children: Thousands of babies like Ivy are born premature every year, but parents can find it an isolating experience

image.altText: A person holds onto some money.

items.synopsis: Newly appointed Fair Work Ombudsman Anna Booth vows to use yet-to-be-legislated criminal penalties against employers who deliberately underpay or rip off their workers.

title.children: New Fair Work Ombudsman vows to use criminal penalties to clamp down on wage theft

image.altText: A completely empty chamber of the House of Representatives with not a single person in the green seats.

items.synopsis: Conjecture continues to circulate online regarding what can be changed about the Voice through legislation in the event of a successful referendum. RMIT ABC Fact Check spoke to experts to clear it up.

title.children: CheckMate: Would a second referendum be needed to make changes to the Voice?

image.altText: A woman closes her eyes while someone performs CPR practice on her

items.synopsis: People are less likely to give a woman CPR due to fears of hurting her or being accused of inappropriate touching. One Australian CPR provider is trying to change that by putting breasts on training mannequins.

title.children: 'My life is worth more than my boobs': Women are less likely than men to receive CPR in public

image.altText: A driver stands in the pits with his arms crossed and an annoyed look on his face.

items.synopsis: After Ford drivers issue a statement calling for a review into an apparent lack of parity, a five-time Bathurst winner weighs in on the debate.

title.children: As Ford drivers complain about a lack of parity with Chevrolet, a Bathurst veteran has weighed in on the controversial debate

image.altText: A young man wearing a high-vis vest sits in the small cockpit of a small plane on an airstrip.

items.synopsis: Kash Douglas, 16, is among a growing number of trainee pilots taking to outback Queensland skies, fuelling hope that teaching more people to fly will stop them from permanently leaving the bush.

title.children: Kash can't drive a car, but he can fly a plane. Can trainee pilots like him keep outback towns alive?

image.altText: A composite illustration of six images of students with small bits of paper covering their eyes and hiding their identities

items.synopsis: Tertiary students could soon have a new watchdog holding universities to account, but some warn that it must have strong powers.

title.children: Student ombudsman on the table as governments crack down on uni sexual assaults

image.altText: Wheelchair basketball

items.synopsis: Kevin Coombs, who attended the very first Paralympics, dies aged 82. Warning: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are warned that the following story contains an image of a deceased person.

title.children: Paralympic community mourns the death of trailblazing wheelchair basketballer Kevin Coombs

image.altText: a group of inmates at a NSW jail walk into a room, which is a classroom

items.synopsis: Mark* never expected to learn algebra, and he definitely didn't think he would pick it up in prison. But the Hunter Correctional Centre inmate is now aiming for a degree in construction management.

title.children: 'Why not release us as civilised human beings?': Inmates pursue uni degrees to break cycle of offending

image.altText: Male rescue workers working near the site of a badly damaged building.Trees in the background.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian officials say a Russian attack on a village in the north-east of the country has killed 51 people, including a child.

title.children: 'No military targets': Russian missile attack kills more than 50 civilians in one of the deadliest strikes in Ukraine war

image.altText: A close-up shows a woman placing a green nut into her mouth

items.synopsis: In PNG's Manus province, dozens of locals have gone missing in treacherous journeys across the seas in search of the addictive betel nut. Some of them drown, but others meet their ends at the hands of other traders, or pirates.

title.children: 'They're killing people at sea': The lucrative PNG trade that gave rise to pirates

image.altText: A man in a suit jacket sits down.

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Yes campaigner Thomas Mayo denounces threats against Lidia Thorpe

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tavleen Singh Rapper Briggs's Yes concert, named Now and Forever kicks off today in Shepparton, Victoria. The activist group A.B. Original released a song titled Yes, delivering an impassioned endorsement of a Yes vote in the referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament. The track featuring Indigenous rapper Briggs, has gone off with over 4 million hits already. "I think that it speaks to that generation," says Briggs on the popularity of the song. "I reckon this is how people are talking in the pubs and in the lounge rooms." An impressive line-up of artists including Paul Kelly, Jimmy Barnes and Hilltop Hoods will be performing at Shepparton today, hoping to inform more people about the Voice referendum. Organised by Briggs, the day-long Yes concert is aimed at undecided voters. "Over the last few weeks, I was just wanting to put more positive stuff into the sphere, because it was like, so much vitriol and so negative," Briggs tells ABC News Breakfast. "And I think that the best way that we can show people what a Yes might look like is by putting a show together with artists that share the same kind of vision for unity and solidarity." Victoria has been inundated with heavy rains this week but the rapper and activist is hopeful the rain will hold off today. Can't make it to the gig? Luckily, there's a First and Forever Special streaming now on iview, showcasing live music highlights from Baker Boy, Briggs & many more.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rapper Briggs's Yes concert, titled Now and Forever, kicks off today

props.alt: A man wears a cap siting down.

children.content: Rapper Briggs has organised the concert.
(ABC News)

"And I think that the best way that we can show people what a Yes might look like is by putting a show together with artists that share the same kind of vision for unity and solidarity."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Today former chief justice of Australia Robert French will be speaking at the National Press Club in Canberra. His address is titled The Voice – Filling a Long Constitutional Silence. He will be speaking from 12:30pm AEDT and we will be bringing it to you live.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coming up today: Robert French speaking at National Press Club

children.content: Today former chief justice of Australia
Robert French
will be speaking at the National Press Club in Canberra.
His address is titled
The Voice – Filling a Long Constitutional Silence.
He will be speaking from 12:30pm AEDT and we will be bringing it to you live.

props.alt: Robert French stands smiling in front of a book shel

children.content: Robert French.
(ABC News: Georgia Hitch)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tavleen Singh Independent senator Lidia Thorpe was tagged in a video of a Neo-Nazi burning an Aboriginal flag while doing a Nazi salute. The Indigenous senator says the police failed to protect her and ministers from across the board including Prime Minister Anthony Albanese have condemned the abuse directed at Ms Thorpe. "There is a question for the no campaign to answer about these sorts of extremists on the no side," says Yes vote advocate Thomas Mayo. He says it is an issue to be answered but people should not forget what the referendum is about. "We can't be distracted. That sort of thing needs to be dealt with but this referendum is ultimately at the end of the day just about recognising Indigenous people by giving us a say," he said speaking on ABC News Breakfast. "It is horrible to see that behaviour and those threats and it is something that we don't want to see in Australian politics." With just over a week left for the Voice to Parliament referendum vote, both sides are making the final push to secure more votes. "We have just got to keep our focus on improving this country, building a better future for our children, for all Australians by saying yes," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'It is horrible': Yes campaigner Thomas Mayo on threats directed at Lidia Thorpe

props.alt: A bald man sits on a couch wearing a blazer.

children.content: Thomas Mayo says the threats against Lidia Thorpe were horrible.
(ABC News)
Reporting by Tavleen Singh
Independent senator
Lidia Thorpe
was tagged in a video of a Neo-Nazi burning an Aboriginal flag while doing a Nazi salute.
The Indigenous senator says the police failed to protect her and ministers from across the board including
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
have condemned the abuse directed at Ms Thorpe.
"There is a question for the no campaign to answer about these sorts of extremists on the no side," says Yes vote advocate
Thomas Mayo.
He says it is an issue to be answered but people should not forget what the referendum is about.

"We can't be distracted. That sort of thing needs to be dealt with but this referendum is ultimately at the end of the day just about recognising Indigenous people by giving us a say," he said speaking on
ABC News Breakfast
"It is horrible to see that behaviour and those threats and it is something that we don't want to see in Australian politics."
With just over a week left for the
Voice to Parliament
referendum vote, both sides are making the final push to secure more votes.
"We have just got to keep our focus on improving this country, building a better future for our children, for all Australians by saying yes," he says.

title.children: Men rescued from rooftop of car in Victorian floodwaters as cost to farmers grows

image.altText: Side by side photos of Lidia Thorpe wearing sunglasses, speaking animatedly to media, and Clare O'Neil during a 7.30 interview

items.synopsis: For decades, being a woman in the public eye has made you fodder for sexist attacks. There are some that take great delight in coming for women who dare lift their head about the parapet, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: 'Very angry': Two scenes this week show what it’s like to be a woman in public life

image.altText: Plants, farmers and dish

items.synopsis: Farmers in Western Australia are turning salty wastelands into pillows of gourmet greens — and they're now in high demand in Australia's best restaurants.

title.children: These salty plants grow in a farming wasteland and could feed the world's growing population

image.altText: A young man in a Hudsons Coffee uniform gives a thumbs up while leaning against a cafe counter.

items.synopsis: More businesses are recognising the benefits of employing people with disability, but "misconceptions and stereotypes" remain, a support agency says.

title.children: More businesses are becoming inclusive for people with disability, and Finn works for one of them

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Australian shares open flat after mixed results on Wall Street overnight. Follow live.

title.children: ASX opens flat, Reserve Bank to release latest financial stability review

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Well, I suppose the ASX futures were technically correct, the ASX 200 and All Ords are every so slightly up (at 0.06% and 0.04% respectively at 10:30am AEDT). 6 of 11 sectors are higher today, led by consumer discretionary (+0.3%) which is rebounding from its recent decline. It's been off -1.5% for the past five days. Materials (+0.1%) and the financial sectors (+0.1%) are also doing well. The losses are led by IT (-0.1%) and the utilities (-0.2%) sectors. The biggest losses are being felt by fund manager Magellan Financial Group which is down about -9%. It's all because it's reported a $4 billion drop in funds under management as of September, down to $35 billion. The top movers are: Paladin Energy (+2%) Telix Pharmaceuticals (+2%) Aristocrat Leisure (+1.7%) Iress Ltd (+1.7%) Weebit Nano (+1.6%) The bottom movers are: Magellan Financial Group (-9%) PEXA Group (-3%) Core Lithium (-2.7%) Resmed (-2%) Sayona Mining (-2%)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX has opened flat this morning

children.content: Well, I suppose the ASX futures were technically correct, the ASX 200 and All Ords are every so slightly up (at 0.06% and 0.04% respectively at 10:30am AEDT).
6 of 11 sectors are higher today, led by consumer discretionary (+0.3%) which is rebounding from its recent decline.
It's been off -1.5% for the past five days.
Materials (+0.1%) and the financial sectors (+0.1%) are also doing well.
The losses are led by IT (-0.1%) and the utilities (-0.2%) sectors.
The biggest losses are being felt by fund manager Magellan Financial Group which is down about -9%.
It's all because it's reported a $4 billion drop in funds under management as of September, down to $35 billion.
The top movers are:
Paladin Energy (+2%)
Telix Pharmaceuticals (+2%)
Aristocrat Leisure (+1.7%)
Iress Ltd (+1.7%)
Weebit Nano (+1.6%)
The bottom movers are:
Magellan Financial Group (-9%)
PEXA Group (-3%)
Core Lithium (-2.7%)
Resmed (-2%)
Sayona Mining (-2%)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A tech upgrade for private health insurer Defence Health was supposed to drag it into the future. Instead, it's left droves of members in the lurch, with some forced to pay huge medical bills for procedures they were supposed to be covered for. Hundreds of members have made complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman about the fiasco. You can continue reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Private health insurer tech glitch leaves some members facing large bills

featuredLink.title: Hundreds of complaints after health insurer's IT glitch leaves customers with big medical bills and unpaid claims

children.content: A tech upgrade for private health insurer Defence Health was supposed to drag it into the future.
Instead, it's left droves of members in the lurch, with some forced to pay huge medical bills for procedures they were supposed to be covered for.
Hundreds of members have made complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman about the fiasco.
You can continue reading this story here:

Farmers have seen their crops wiped out and infrastructure wash away, costing them millions.

image.altText: A woman with a bandaged leg on a stretcher being wheeled to an ambulance.

items.synopsis: Kate Miller, 62, was bitten by a brown snake on a beach in northern New South Wales, 136 kilometres away from a hospital. A compression bandage from by a passer-by may have saved her life.

title.children: Beachgoers warned to 'be really aware' after grandmother bitten by snake during solo surf trip

image.altText: Two Australian players congratulate each other following the dismissal of a West Indian opponent.

items.synopsis: Another big knock from skipper Hayley Matthews is not enough to get West Indies over the line, as Australia wraps up the T20 international series with a 47-run triumph at Brisbane's Allan Border Field.

title.children: Aussies claim T20 series victory over Windies despite Matthews's heroics

image.altText: New Zealand cricketers celebrate.

items.synopsis: England's Cricket World Cup title defence is off to the worst possible start thanks to a rampant New Zealand.

title.children: Defending champions England thrashed by NZ in World Cup opener
